en: Don't care. Go away.
Take all the time you need, sweetie. I'll be right here.
Will you be back in time for dinner?
See you later honey! Don't be a stranger!
I'll see you next time!
They don't seem to mind.
You'll be back soon. No one can resist my call for long.
Time for a little nap
You knock on the door.
No response. Well, you hear some cackling from a distance, but it doesn't seem targeted at you
There's a witch in the kitchen. She appears to be raiding the cupboards. Quite voraciously, too. Anything you say is bound to startle her.
choice_2: Those cookies go well with killer mushrooms ?
choice_3: Um....hi ? Which one are you again ?

en: Her eyes are wide as saucers. Her skin goes pale. Well, pale-er.
"Umm... yes? No? Is that a trick question?"
"No-one! None of us! ...of them! Je ne parle pas anglais!"
She scampers off without saying a word, still carrying the spoils of her nighttime raid on the kitchen.
She scampers off before you can respond, still carrying the spoils of her nighttime raid on the kitchen.
Various cookies and biscuits, abandoned in her flight, form a trail of all-too-literal breadcrumbs behind her leading into the garden. Still, she's nowhere to be seen.
But when you close your eyes, you swear you can hear someone, somewhere in the distance.
Munching.
BLASTED CREATURE, WILL YOU STOP THAT RUCKUS?!
KNOCK ONE MORE TIME AND I’LL REND YOUR SOUL FROM YOUR BODY AND SHACKLE IT TO MY –
Oh. It’s you.
What are you after, agent of the beyond? Have you finally come for my soul?
I, uh, wasn’t, uh, hiding, by the way.
A woman of my stature simply has more important concerns than… whatever you’re currently scurrying after. Yes, that’s it. Anyway...
What did you want?
choice_2: What do you think about the murder?
choice_3: I need to show you something.

en: She runs a hand through her hair and gives you a look so sharp it can only be born from hours of practice in front of a bathroom mirror.
Heh. You wish to act like you don’t already know who i am?
That’s alright. I don’t mind giving out a little refresher course.
A heart of ice! A face sculpted from marble! A soul of mycellium!
The commoners call me Queen, Empress, the Mushroom Mother, the Lurker Below, the Chanterelle Enchantress and one time a child at the mall even called me the Lady With the Scary Face.
Every mushroom on this earth is an extension of my being. I don’t need to spend my time devising plans to control the world – I already do.
You can call me “My Lady”, or perhaps “Mistress”. But I will allow “Germaine".
She stares off into the distance, sullen and somber.
A grisly affair. Dark forces beyond even my knowledge conspired against this poor girl.
It’s not the most awkward silence you’ve ever suffered through. But it’s close.
If you were under the impression I wanted to discuss it at length, I fear I have terrible news for you.
I wasn’t close to Vicky, but I still feel her loss deeply. A queen mourns all her subjects, regardless of size, loyalty, or, yes, ridiculous magical abilities.
Thank goodness she wasn’t found with any mushrooms on her, or else your puny mind would be tempted to suspect I had any involvement in this ghastly matter.
Can you leave now? You’re not the only urgent business needing my attention.
Ooh, is it shiny? Is it precious? I love being shown things.
She stares at it knowingly. Appraises it. Silently, her analysis is concluded, and her judgement is rendered.
...and?
She doesn’t even try to hide the drool leaking from her mouth or the stars in her eyes. This is probably the closest she’s ever been to true happiness.
I need it. I must have it.
Give it to me.
Hand it over, or watch the world burn.
It takes some time to convince her not to eat the evidence.
Her disgust is palpable.
This creature they call Mithra. She has an uncanny ability to always know what will annoy me the most.
She’s… no, that can’t be right. Is … Is that gratitude in her eyes? You must be mistaken.
That’s… It can’t be. She didn’t eat it? That means I’m… I’m not…
It’s not my fault?
Heh. Of course it’s not my fault. How could I think for a second it ever could have been?
Forgive this moment of absence, my subjects. Surely even I am allowed to make a mistake once every few centuries.
If the sun shines a little brighter in the sky today, that’s only because It saw me smile.
Me, hiding something? Pah.
I have secrets like the night sky has stars. If you found something, could you even understand it?
Hah. And for a second I thought I had something to worry about.
That’s right. Suzie came to me some days ago inquiring about a sleep remedy for her beloved.
How could I listen to the plight of one of my subjects and remain unmoved? Any queen only does what’s best for her people.
Naturally I had mushrooms for this issue. I have mushrooms for every issue. So I gave her one to ease her sleep and sweeten her dreams.
That’s all there was to this.
Now THIS might be the most awkward silence you’ve ever suffered through.
I GAVE HER THE WRONG MUSHROOM, OKAY??
I MADE A MISTAKE! DOESN’T EVERYONE MAKE MISTAKES?! SURELY I’M ALLOWED ONE TOO, FROM TIME TO TIME?!
I THOUGHT I HAD GIVEN HER THE RIGHT ONE! By the time I realized I had gotten them mixed up, Suzie was already halfway through the mansion.
What was I going to do, go searching after her like some kind of underpaid hireling? Then crawl on my belly, and… apologize?
Saying that word out loud did not come easy to her.
Besides, it’s not like that mistake could even have any consequences! How could eating a levitating mushroom lead to someone’s death? It just makes you float!
I mean, unless she ate it in the high-ceiling hallway before going to sleep. Then she’d probably fall to the ground the second the effect expired, and splatter all over the carpet.
But there’s NO CHANCE that could EVER happen!
What a bummer. I really liked those carpets.
There’s a tiny witch perched above the gigantic creature, gently nestled in its fur.
They’re both asleep, but you’re not sure which one of them is snoring the loudest.
choice_1: Can you tell me about yourselves?
choice_2: Do either of you know anything about the murder?
choice_3: I need to show you something.

en: The creature cautiously sniffs at you. When it seems satisfied you’re not a threat, it lets out a series of grunts and whines. It’s quite verbose, really, as grunts go.
You have no clue what it just said, though. But it seems very proud of itself and what it claims to be, so you decide not to push the issue.
You do wish you had walked away from this encounter with a better descriptor for the creature than wolf-bear-dog...lion...thing.
But life is about making compromises. Sometimes with unusual creatures.
The creature clears its throat, like a thespian preparing for his climactic tirade.
Its eulogy begins as a soft wail, but gently, one by one, every blade of grass seems to join its choir.
Soon, some of the nearby trees start swaying to its song, and before long, the entire garden is singing along for the dead witch.
If they had the tools for it, you could swear they’d be crying.
Abruptly, the song stops, and the trees fall still. The creature is coughing. It’s a violent, raucous, hacking noise, and it seems almost as uncomfortable for it as it is for you.
The creature is clearly in pain, like a cat struggling to cough up a hairball.
To your surprise, you discover a sensation you’d thought forgotten. Is that… empathy for the creature? Ew.
Surely there’s something you could do to help. If only to rid yourself of that disgusting feeling.
The creature’s nose perks up. Even the sleeping witch looks excited at the prospect.
The snoring is deafeningly loud. You’re pretty sure they’re doing it on purpose.
The creature’s cough is painful to hear. There’s something stuck in there, struggling to be born.
The creature recoils. It seems to have, if not a fear, at least a cautious wariness of anything fungal.
The creature recoils. It seems to have, if not a fear, at least a cautious wariness of anything fungal.
The creature recoils. It seems to have, if not a fear, at least a cautious wariness of anything fungal.
It spits on the ground, clearly angry. Or maybe it’s just making sure it’s all gone.
You lock eyes with the beast. The tension is palpable, only slightly undermined by the witch’s loud and incongruous snoring.
A snort. It's... laughing? You're pretty sure they're laughing at you. Stop that. Stop laughing. That's very mean.
It doesn’t even wait for you to say anything. It lunges at the firkin and starts lapping up the honey with its frankly revoltingly big tongue.
The garden is filled with sounds of slurping and squelching you’d rather not discuss in polite company, as the beast gulps down the entire barrel.
This goes on for some time.
Once its feast has finished, it prepares itself for a single, powerful, magnificent cough. You hold on tightly to your hat as it breathes in.
The beast huffs and puffs and very nearly blows down the mansion, rattling its foundations and shaking its spires.
Along with the hair and pus, you spy a glint of gold in the abnormally large hairball it has left on the ground.
It’s wagging its tail and looking at you expectantly. Fine, you suppose.
You gently pet it and it goes back to sleep with maybe the biggest smile you’ve ever seen on anything living.
All the clocks here are out of tune. They all display wildly different times, and can’t even agree on how long a second should last.
It sounds like a thousand typewriters racing each other.
STOP RIGHT THERE! Her Heavenly Highness’ Horological Office is closed for the day! No visitors!
Unless, of course, you’re here for tea and biscuits. There’s always time for tea and biscuits.
You're right on time!
choice_2: What do you know about the murder?
choice_3: I need to show you something.

en: She thinks for a second, and you swear you can hear the cogs in her head turning. There’s an audible “click” when she’s ready to speak.
Special Agent Mithra Noume, Her Majesty’s Horological Office, appointed caretaker of timeline 862bis – that’s yours – three-time savior of the waking world –
– twice decorated by the order of the clockwork crane, and, if I may say so myself, I bake some damn fine scones in my spare time.
Heh. Spare time.
Get it?
Whatever. If you laugh at that, it messes up the timeline anyway.
Then we’d really be in the weeds. They’re not keen on sending cleanup crews this far out in the boonies, so I’d have to handle it myself.
Great job, everyone. Continuity preserved. You may proceed to ask for a little milk in your tea.
You happily oblige.
Speaking of continuity, has Temmie told you you need to knock 5 times on Germaine’s door down in the garden to get her to open up, or not yet?
It’s not a secret knock or anything. It’s mostly a matter of annoying her until she gives in.
O-Oh. She hadn’t. You weren’t supposed to know that yet.
Oh well. I’m sure it’s no big deal. Happy trails!
Hmph. The question is, what do YOU know about the murder?
I mean, at this point in time. I don’t want to give you information you’re not supposed to have yet.
I’m also not supposed to say that, because now you know there’s information to be found. Be a dear and pretend you’ll be normal about it.
You sagely nod, saying you’ll take her advice into consideration.
Have you at LEAST found the scarecrow already?
No, no, I must be getting my strings mixed up. That one’s gotta be next year. Or maybe last year. Doesn’t matter. Same thing.
Heh. Next year.
...Get it?
Whatever. It’s like a clock, you know?
Tick-tock.
There’s no difference between time and the machinery that defines it. The gears are the concept. The understanding of reality is the reality.
Stop thinking this is irrelevant! I can hear you all the way from back then. It’s a clock! Can you see? It's important that you see.
I mean, I guess it’s not news, really. It’s always clocks all the way down. It’s all cogs and gears and chains, turning, clicking.
But it’s especially true here! That’s not a spoiler, too, I’m pretty sure.
You feel it already, right? Why else would you have been summoned? Surely you can put 2 and 2 together.
If it was just about magic, they wouldn’t need to dial for help.
7 witches in this house, and yet not a trace of a zap or a woosh or a sparkle here. Not even a tiny, itty-bitty little ka-zam.
How does a witch kill a witch without any magic being used at any point?
Yes, yes. Let’s get it over with. I don’t have all the time in the world, you know.
Oh yeah, that’s a crucial piece of the puzzle. For sure. You’re doing great. Keep up the good work!
Leaving, going, coming back. It’s all ebb and flow.
Tick and tock.
Her time of death? Says what incompetent clock?
We all die when it’s our time. Any timepiece that claims to know what time that is in detail is a fraud and a charlatan.
She eyes it like a tiger in a zoo, looking over at the wildcats in the next exhibit. A strange mixture of judgment, pity and motherly instinct.
You poor thing! What did they do to you?
Here, don’t worry, I’ll fix you right up. For free, too. Hush, don’t start, I’m not having any of this.
The doctor takes her patient to the operating table. “Scalpel”, she says. “Screwdriver”. You don't get a say in the matter.
Some time later, the exhausted surgeon and her feline assistant share scones after a successful operation.
She’ll make it, I think. I mean, her cogs will keep on turning. I just hope she can recover mentally. That’s always the hardest with this type of thing.
Breaks my heart, you know. There’s nothing sadder than a clock being forced to lie.
She hands you back Vicky’s alarm clock.
Either you just spent a lot less time in that workshop than you thought, or that clock is now pointing to an hour earlier than it did when you came in.
Heh. Less time than you thought.
Get it?
Whatever.
Say. You know, I’ve been thinking.
I mean, you know how Vicky’s room is on top of the tower at night.
You know. Right above the hallway.
And she fell to her death. Well. Presumably.
If that sleepyhead set her alarm too early, and just walked out her door still half-asleep without paying attention…
I mean.
Surely not, right?
A short, energetic witch whose safety equipment probably weighs more than her is standing alone against a hurricane of critters of various shapes and sizes.
What’s worse, she seems to be winning.
What can I do for ya?
choice_1: What is it you do here?
choice_2: Do you know anything about the murder?
choice_3: I need to show you something.

en: A puzzlingly colorful imp comes at you with sharp claws and gnashing teeth.
A hand, wrapped in a glove as thick as your arm, grabs it an inch before it reaches your face.
Bertrand!! What did I tell you about eating guests?! Play nice!
She admonishes the creature. From what you gather, its television privileges have been revoked, and it will not be tasting ice cream for the foreseeable future.
It seems to be sulking.
Hi, hi, hello hi!! It’s a pleasure to meet you! Everyone around calls me Mrs. Ink!
This is my menagerie!! Don’t worry, they’re friendly, they don’t bite. Well, unless they’re REALLY hungry, or they’re just feeling extra playful.
Some clown-colored… thing lunges at her, and she catches it mid-air.
Why YES Geoffrey, of COURSE I mean you! Who’s a perfectly demonic little guy? Yes you are, yes you are!
She tries to keep it down for a few seconds, fails miserably, and starts crying uncontrollably.
I CAN’T BELIEVE SHE’S DEAD!!
That poor, poor girl! I loved her like a daughter and I’ll never get to talk to her again…
If there’s anything I can do to help you, just say the word! I promise I’ll do whatever I can.
Her attention briefly turns to the assortment of monsters crowding at her feet expectantly.
And they’ll help too, of course!
Oh goodie! It’s still alive, I hope?
The imp known as “Bertrand” tries to wrestle it out of your hand.
Put that down! You don't know where it's been! Though I confess, dearie, I’ve no clue what you want me to do with this.
Yes, dearie? You’ll want to know if I heard anything, I suppose.
Yes, dearie? You’ll want to know if I heard anything, I suppose.
Makes sense, my room’s right next to the hallway at night. We’ll, I’m happy to report I heard absolutely nothing!
Oh, that’s not the answer you were looking, for, was it. Oh, dearie me. Oh, I’m so sorry sweetie.
Wait! Maybe this’ll help you a little. I like when things are done just right, so I always wake up on the same schedule.
And I always wake up a little before morning, to get to the kitchen ahead of everyone else and fetch some treats for my little monsters.
That’s when I found the body! Whatever killed the poor girl, it must have happened before morning.
Gosh, did I just help the investigation? Maybe I should be a detective!
I don’t have your dashing good looks though, I’m told those help.
Oh, poor thing! I’ve been hearing that poor creature whine like that for days! Temmie’s always too busy to come and ask for help herself.
Say, I can’t bear to sit around and do nothing hearing it suffer like that!
Could you take this to him? I’m sure he’ll know what to do with it.
It should help! I mean. I hope!
Oh. Ooh. And they… really? In this house? And… Together? Oh. Oh my.
Her face goes redder than her carpets.
Well of course vicky wanted to leave! She’s still young, you know, barely a few centuries old.
Not like these old bones. There’s no other place I could go where I could raise this brood of mine.
Such a pity. Maybe whenever I bring these little rascals on vacation, I’ll bring a picture of her along. Show her a bit of the world.
She’s baking up a storm. A little too literally, in your opinion.
A witch is staring wistfully into the night.
Hi there, little buddy! I’m Delilah. But all my friends call me Del, so you can too!
What can lil’ ol’ me do for you?
choice_1: Can you tell me about yourself?
choice_2: What do you know about the murder?
choice_3: I need to show you something.

en: Well, I started by spending my first 2 decades out of school at the Court of Flowers, cooking for Titania.
But they didn’t renew my contract after it expired.
Something about the royal kitchens not being a place suited to mayhem, explosions, and other – ah, what was it? – “culinary expressions of exuberant personality”.
Between you and me, I just think they were too cheap to keep up with the repairs.
Brokies.
So then I went backpacking in the mountains of Peru for a year –
Oh. Is that not really relevant right now?
Well, you’re the detective! Can’t you, I don’t know, detect what I do here? It’s not exactly rocket science!
That’d be more up Mithra’s alley.
Well, not much, considering I didn’t do it, and it wasn’t done to me neither. So, really, I don’t know what you want me to know about it.
You struggle to find the words to explain why it’s not actually that easy to just ask the killer (or the victim) about their murder.
She seems to imply that maybe you’re just bad at your job.
Anyway, if that’s all you wanted to ask, go, scram, scamper! I’ve got cakes to feed and mouths to bake!
There’s nothing I can even tell you about the victim. I didn’t know her, or anyone who knew her.
Complete stranger, even if she did really like the biscuits I made for he- I mean, for everyone.
I make biscuits for everyone. Always.
Uh-huh. And pass me the sesame too, while you’re at it.
She observes it closely and, before you can stop her, starts sniffing the evidence.
...I suppose I could make some kind of novelty pie with this. That IS why you’re showing it to me, right?
Aw, poor Suz.
She’s not shy, she’s just… I mean… I shouldn’t be the one to say it. It’s just not really my place, y’know?
Still, someone needs to make sure she’s okay.
We can’t have her stay cooped up in her room like that for days, it’s just not healthy. I’m not sure she’s even eaten anything since…
Well, you know. Since Vicky died. It’s pretty natural she’d take it hard. Everyone else lost a friend, or maybe a colleague.
...I guess that also makes her the prime suspect, right?
Man, that sucks. Please go easy on her at least. She may not look it, but she’s a good girl.
And… please?
Tell her I love her, okay?
Is that… Aw, fiddlesticks. That… Aw, that’s just painful. I’m sorry Suz.
She’s practically licking her lips.
Now THAT I could use. You got some to spare? You could just hand it over and get some more from Mrs. Ink. Say you lost it. Pretty please?
She starts sweating profusely.
I mean it. You’d better get to high ground. Hop on a stove or something. And pray the housekeeper has enough mops and buckets.
So… um… Why would you show me that? What makes you think I could have anything to do with this?
I mean, there’s like, mushrooms on it. And stuff. That’s not my area. Germaine does the mushrooms, remember?
And, um, also, it looks like whoever cooked this used wayyy too much pixie dust. A complete rookie mistake, certainly not one someone as experienced as ME could make.
Egads! Would you look at that! Almost my entire pixie dust supply is gone?!
It seems you’ve not only a murder to solve, but a robbery too. Someone must have infiltrated my kitchen and baked this cake in secret!
Sometimes the best course of action is no action at all.
I mean, really. It’s actually insulting you think I baked this. ME? You think I would make such a simple, basic cake?
Shucks. You’re a tough nut to crack, aren’t you? You got me. I baked Vicky that cake the night before she died, what about it?
She came to me with a mushroom I’d never seen before, said she was afraid to eat it raw. Asked if I could bake it into something for her.
What’s it got to do with her death, anyway? It’s just cake.
You recount the story that could make her, if not directly responsible, at least an accessory to the crime. She goes pale.
Waitwaitwait-no, no, that’s not right. That can’t be right.
And I can prove it.
But…
Oh, man. Please… promise you won’t tell  the others.
That magic mushroom didn’t go into the cake. I kept it for myself.
It just… You know! It just looked so dang tasty! I’d never seen anything like it before!
I haven’t even had the opportunity to eat it yet. It’s still around here somewhere.
She rummages through her seemingly-bottomless cupboards for a while, then hands you a mushroom.
Here.
It’s the missing mushroom alright. Colorful, grotesque, and so frustratingly, insultingly, thoroughly un-eaten.
The door’s locked. There’s a sticky note on it, attached again with tape for good measure.
“GO AWAY!! BUSY! SCRAM! GET OUT! BLEH!”, it reads rather chalantly.
That could be meant for you. Though, more likely, it’s been here for years.
choice_1: There's something I need to show you.
choice_2: I guess I'll come back later.

en: Despite all your gusto, the door remains frustratingly closed.
Without a word, the lock clicks open. Then another, and another.
...And another. The witch leaves the unlocked door ajar. What, you need her to hold it open for you, princess? Be serious. Go in.
An aura of gloom, morosity and melodrama surrounds this place. And that smell. Dear god. And in the eye of that storm of despair –
‘Sup, asshole. Waddaya want.
Scratch that. Don’t care.

choice_2: What do you know about the murder ?
choice_3: I need to show you something.

en: She gives you a look full of disdain and carefully practiced disinterest. Outside, the thunder rolls as the rain bangs against the windows. That’s probably her doing too.
Ugh, Fine. Name’s Suzie. Suzie Piscious. Del calls me Suz. Please don’t.
I do magic. I’m a witch. Cool, right? You don’t care either. Cool.
Whatever. I’m guessin’ Del told you? ‘Bout me n Vic?
She sighs, and you swear you can hear the building heave.
I’ll miss her. At least she gets to be a ghost now. That’s sick. I wish I could be a ghost.
Now leave me alone or I’ll haunt you first.
Well, everything. Except actually I know jack shit. We were hangin’, that evening. Last I saw her? Musta been…
Well after nightfall, for sure. Prolly a lil’ after midnight. Hour o’ the wolf, I’m guessin’.
Anythin’ happened to her, musta happened after that.
‘Cause I’m innocent. In case you hadn’t got that already.
We weren’t talking ‘bout much. Just hangin’, y’know? Me despairing the insatisfaction inherent to life, n her tryin’ to cheer me up.
Smotherin’ me in her radiance. Makes me wanna puke just thinkin’ about it.
You never feel it, cat? The hunger? Like a constant gnawing at the edge of your mind. There’s rats in the walls.
Only, no matter how many walls they bite through, there’ll always be another to squirm against.
This hypothetical endless buffet of rats seems rather appealing to you. You’re not sure what her metaphor was supposed to be.
Anyway, I got her a gift earlier. Maybe look into that. If you care.
She said she’d been having trouble sleepin’. Insomnia and the like. Sleepwalking too. Shit sucks.
So I asked my friend Germaine for help. Y’know, if she had something for that.
She gave me this rad-looking shroom for her, and I passed it along to Vic. Maybe that’s somethin’.
Maybe not. Whatever.
She rolls her eyes. Spectacularly so.
Ugh, Fine. Let’s get this over with.
Cool. Don’t care. Can you go away now?
... Yeah? So what?
She visibly recoils at the thing. It’s like she abhors the very existence of this item.
What, you needed one? Coulda just asked.
She’s visibly upset. You can tell from the total lack of change in her expression or demeanor.
Wait, scratch that. She’s not upset. She’s… Puzzled? Distraught?
What’s this about? I know we had a bit of a fight, but like… Wasn’t that bad, y’know? Shit…
Was the same fight we always had, too. Vic, she was… She always hated this house. Hated any house she stayed in for too long, really.
She was always burning with desire. Wanted to do everything. See everything. Taste everything. Even a witch’s lifetime was too short for that girl.
She couldn’t bear staying cooped up in this house. It ate at her.
But I’m like… me, y’know? All forlorn and despaired. I can’t leave this house of a thousand comforts for, what… Harsh mattresses and uncertain bedtimes?
So we argue. She pushes, I pull, we kiss, and we repeat the dance the next day.
Guess we’re done dancing.
She sighs, and retreats into silence.
You need a hand with anything?
Well of course! That’s what I’m here for.
Oh dear, is Suzie being uncooperative again?
It’s always some trouble or other with the Piscious twins. Maybe her sister Delilah can help you with that one.
Temmie’s pet is always in some trouble. I’ve lost count of how many times Mrs. Ink has had to bail them both out of sticky situations.
It is pretty fortunate for him we have such a menagerie expert in the mansion, you know.
Oh goodness! That looks delicious! Is it also edible by humans, or only suited to unnaturally green monsters twice my size?
Always the difficult one, that Germaine. Her room’s under the garden. “Her room”. More of a cave than anything, but that’s just how she likes it.
Damp and moist and dark and dusty. Says it’s good for growth.
Have you established when the time of death was? If I was you, I’d try talking to the people who could have seen her around the time she died.
Have you established when the time of death was? If I was you, I’d try talking to the people who could have seen her around the time she died.
Mrs Ink’s room is right next to Vicky’s at night, maybe she heard something.
I’m well aware dearie. I know everything that goes down under this roof. That’s their business, and none of mine.
Maybe it’s Suzie you’d rather discuss this with?
Oh dear, a magic sleep mushroom? There’s a thousand ways that could go wrong.
She must have got it from Germaine, right?
Why doesn’t that look just delicious! It’s both a cake and a mushroom. Though I’m not sure our local baker would share my enthusiasm for this particular piece.
Ah, that’s just sad. I’m sorry Suzie. But accepting what’s gone, and never coming back… That’s just part of life I’m afraid.
What’s wrong with the clock, dear? Oh. Nothing? Well, you best get that checked up, then. Sounds like a severe condition.
I’m sure Mithra would be happy to help.
That’s the missing mushroom! But I thought Vicky ate it? What’s it doing here?
You are right though. That thing looks downright noxious.
Is that what Temmie’s pet was choking on this whole time? Well, glad to hear he’s safe at least.
If you don’t see the room yet, I’m sure it’ll show up given enough time.
Things just have a way of… turning up in this house.
She sighs wistfully. On her face is the kind of resigned melancholy that would get her a choice spot in a small, family-owned renaissance art museum.
Well, I wouldn’t know anything about that dear. I’m a little magical myself, but I’m incapable of using any of it.
But it did seem weird to me that I hadn’t seen or heard any kind of magic used. Dearie me.
Thunder strikes. Rain pours. And you? You wait.
An evening like this one? There’s going to be a case. There’s always a case out there, waiting to be solved by Shorthair Holmes.
Any time now, some tragic dame is going to come knocking at your door spinning her tale of star-crossed lovers and gut-wrenching revenge.
Aaaany time now.
Wait, what the-
Oh, goodie, he showed up!
I’ve been told it’s rather rude to conduct summonings at breakfast, dear.
Hpmh. We lie betwixt the jaws of the beast. There are more important things to focus on than “breakfast”.
Del, pass the pixie cakes?
Witches. Of course, it just *had* to be witches. While two of them are busy gorging themselves, the sheepish creature turns to you.
I’m sorry honey, you must be very confused. But breakfast is the most important meal of the day, and murder or not, that’s still true.
Of course there’s been a murder, don’t be silly. Why else would they have called you here?
Finally. Mystery. Intrigue. Purrpose.
You ask to be brought to the crime scene, desperate to be away from this horrid display of carbohydrates and heightened blood sugar.
Oh. I’m afraid they’re sitting on it, dear.
You see, this is where we found our dearly departed Vicky this morning. Well, we found her a little all over the room, really. She’d made quite a mess.

Of course, I cleaned it right up. I can’t stand anything being messy in this house.
Del she was eeeverywhere! Can’t have breakfast looking at that.
Her grisly yet spectacular demise seems consistent with falling down from high up. Or explosion. Or, now that I think about it, about two dozen magic spells.
That I know of.
Course, that means there’s no crime scene for you to sniff at. Poor kitty! You’ll just have to ask around, instead.
There’s six witches left in this house, not counting the housekeeper over there. One of us – uh, of them – musta done it! ‘Cause it’s not me!
It’s not me either, you simpleton. Stop looking at me like that or I’ll turn you into a newt.
Well, then I also must confess. It wasn’t me.
Now go on then! Scram! Investigize! Detectivate!
And if you need help with anything, I’ll always be here. Happy to help. It’s not like there’s anywhere else I could be anyway! My soul is bound to this place.
Wait! Bide your time for but an instant. It would be most unwise to set out now. The time of shifting is upon us.
They must be idiots if they think you’re going to ask what that is. Nope, don’t care.
But before you can muster a disinterested sneer, you feel the ground shake under you. It’s as if the entire manor is being torn apart from the inside.
And then, as abruptly as it started, it just… stops. The gears creak to a halt, the chains stop clicking and the corridors open up again.
Don’t be scared! The manor just… does that. There’s gotta be thousands of rooms in here, so it makes only the ones we need accessible!
Three times a day, the layout changes to suit the needs of the witches who reside in this coven.
And also, because it’s really cool! Now get a move on, we don’t have all day. Solve that murder!
The sound of the key turning in the lock is apparently indistinguishable from a call to dinner. By the time the door opens, Suzie and Mrs Ink are walking over each other to get in.
Y’know, if you needed her room key. You coulda just asked.
Oh dearie me, it’s so messy in there! How can a girl live like this?
Suzie shoots her a look, and she has the decorum to pretend not to notice it.
So, cat, anything useful in here?
Ew.
Goodness! Keep that away from my babies. It’ll disappear before you can blink.
Suzie is scrounging around somewhere on the other side of the room. Probably for the best she doesn’t see this right now.
Is that… Oh. Oh, my. They really were very good friends, weren’t they?
Suzie is making a face like a cat who just learnt it’s bath time. It’s like this object is anathema to her very existence.
Hisss…..
There’s no knock at the door. In fact, there’s no door anymore. Moira bursts in, with a look you didn’t think her face could make.
Enough of this charade! You have all the evidence you need.
It wasn’t that hard of a case, now let’s put 2 and 2 together – together.
All the others are already in the parlor. We’re waiting for you.
Ahem! Ahem! I must apologise to you all, there was never a “pizza night” in the cards today.
There’s an audible groan from the audience.
No, instead, I’ve gathered you all here so we can all answer one very simple question!
Suzie, why did you kill Vicky?
Come on now, don’t be shy.
...Excuse you?
Suzie?! It was you? How could you do that to poor Vicky?
I couldn’t, and I didn’t! What the hell?
I’ve pleaded with the Dark Ones for help on this.
They said they didn’t care, so we’re on our own.
Hmph! If you insist on being so stubborn, let’s recap the facts ou –frankly adorable–detective put together.
Everyone knows you fought all the time! Until the day before she died, that is. When she said you’d never fight again.
Temmie’s snoring is slow and solemn, echoing through the high halls of the parlor.
You’ve always been a spoiled little brat! You couldn’t accept there was something she wanted more than you!
So you asked your only friend Germaine here for a poison with suitable plausible deniability –
Poison?! How dare you speak of my beautiful children like that?!
Her… Only friend? Yeah, you can’t really pretend to be surprised.
– and you had it baked into that dreadful cake by your sister, who you knew would always side with you!
Dreadful? Beg your pardon?
You knew full well what ingredients you were cooking with, dearie. You’ve just never been able to refuse your sister anything.
I must thank you for uncovering the dreadful truth of this matter, detective.
Even if I can only despair at how tragic it is.
It's no big deal, Suzie. It's just murder. You can own up to it.
Yeah Suzie, you're a big girl! Take some responsibility for once.
I admit I would love to see that.
…But that’s insane! I didn’t kill her! I… I loved her.
Cat, tell me this isn’t your fault. I knew you were an idiot. But it can’t be that bad.
She’s being very mean, but that doesn't make her wrong. Even if Suzie’s the killer, that can’t be the story behind it.
There’s a very simple reason why.
Ha of course! I get it. Allow me.
Wait, no. I don't get it. At all.
That’s right! That’s a nice story, but it doesn’t make sense!
The mushroom’s right here! Yeah! So I’m a greedy goblin. So I wanted to keep it for myself.
Well sometimes, in this incredibly specific and convoluted scenario, greed does pay off!
You… Kept it? Del, can you please not steal my girlfriend’s shit?
Hey! That’s a very rude thing to say to someone who just proved you innocent.
No, that doesn’t ring right. It doesn’t prove her innocence.
She's right. All it does is prove that version of events isn’t exactly what happened. Even if that specific mushroom wasn’t the murder weapon…
There’s no one else with a credible motive!
And especially not me.
Thank goodness.
That’s a lie! We didn’t break up.
You’re still hiding something, you brat! If you didn’t, why is that photo ripped up?!
It’s not like anyone else could have done it for her!
Or I suppose you could have ripped it up yourself. After you killed her. Symbolically.
After all, you’re the only other person with access to her room, as you’ve so loudly proclaimed.
It’s true. She did say that.
Wait. That’s not right.
There is someone else. Someone who could have gotten into that room. But who?
Temmie is still snoring loudly, in case you were wondering. It’s not doing wonders for the dramatic tension of the moment.
The clock strikes twelves! He’s right. Suzie is the only witch here with access to Vicky’s room... But she’s not the only person.
Gasp! Surely you don’t mean…
I don’t actually know who you mean. Please say who you mean.
The housekeeper, Germaine. She’s got a master key. It’s kind of crucial to her job.
She… She does?! Has… Has she been in my room? Why wasn’t I made aware of this?!
It is part of a housekeeper’s pride to see the embarassing erotica collection scattered across the room of her residents, and have the decorum to never mention it.
Wait, pause. As much as I believe in my own innocence – and I do, on account of, y’know, being innocent – why would the housekeeper tear up that photo?
Well, our feline detective here seems to be implying I did it to frame you.
How I would know to frame you for a crime before it ever happens is, however, beyond me.
Do you mind enlightening us on this nonsense, sweetie?
They’re completely right. It makes no sense for the housekeeper to enter Vicky’s room to tear that picture.
Good thing that’s not the reason she went there in the first place, then.
Ha of course! I get it. Allow me.
Wait, no. I don't get it. At all.
Great googly moogly, he does know how to do his job! You weren’t in there to tear up the photo.
You were in there to commit the murder!
Commit the… Murder? In a different room than the one the murder took place in?
The murder of my beautiful baby’s innocence! That alarm will never tick right again, because of what you did to it!
And while you were up to your dastardly deeds, you got the idea to tear that photo to frame Suzie!
Dastardly deeds? But… How could she have killed Vicky remotely?
And without using magic?
You lot can’t tie your shoelaces without using magic! God forbid someone have a little imagination.
There’s no need to get anyone’s hands dirty. With how little sleep she’d been getting, if you set her alarm clock to a little earlier than normal…
Say, for example, to while the house was shifting…
...There’s no way that sleepyhead would ever notice! She’d just try to walk out the door for breakfast…
..And fall down three stories to the spectacular death she met at the hands of the hallway floor.
While our kindly housekeeper enjoys a good night’s sleep, ready to discover the bad news along with everyone else the in the morning.
That’s… Quite the story sweetie.
But, not only do you have no proof for any of this, besides a stacking of circumstances less stable than a jenga tower.
That fairytale of yours is missing something a lot more basic than that.
Why, oh why, would this sweet old lady, who has never known anything but comfort and kindness, ever want any harm to befall poor Vicky?
What on earth could be my motive for this?
Little bit of a spoiler warning on this one, dearie. There isn’t one.
She’s right.
Wait, is she?
There is a motive. Because there’s always a motive. Or else, we’ve been playing a faulty game this entire time. And that’s even worse than a killer without a motive.
And just like that, looking at your notes, you do find one that fits the bill.
Ha of course! I get it. Allow me.
Wait, no. I don't get it. At all.
Huh? Oh. Ooh, I get it.
Would you look at that. Vicky was the victim of a fit of passionate jealousy after all.
Just… not from me.
I wasn’t the only one in love in here. You’ve got a sweetheart of your own, don’t you?
This place.
Well, she doesn’t have much choice, really. In her position, if she wasn’t in love with the place…
I mean, it’s not like she can leave. Her soul’s bound to the place. She’s been here for centuries.
But nothing lasts forever. Not even love.
Except desire.
Leave a rat in a cage, and given enough time, he’ll learn to forget his chains.
Maybe even fall in love with the bars. Forget there’s a world waiting, just outside his reach.
It's been here for quite a long time.
But after you break him like that. If you lie next to him and show him the stars for the first time in his life. Tell him about everything he can’t ever hope to reach.
In excruciating detail.
Don’t you think he’d bite? If only just to see if he still can?
And would you blame him?
Oh, Vic…
Go on, agent of the beyond. You know you want to wedge the last nail in that coffin yourself.
You don’t wedge nails into coffins. This girl wouldn't last a day in a funeral home. Still.
This is why the housekeeper had to kill Vicky.
Dearie, it's the climactic moment. Could you be serious for a minute, please?
Good kitty.
The Housekeeper says nothing. She gives the garden one long look, like lovers on either side of a train window. Then she starts walking.
Deeper into the manor.
When she reaches the place between rooms, a long, winding corridor, she stops and sits neatly on the ground, crossing her legs.
And she waits.
Can’t be too much longer, now.
Dearie, it's the climactic moment. Could you be serious for a minute, please?
Oh my sweet little Patricia is also starting to lose her sight. Cataract is a real pain.
Perhaps our feline detective is perceiving reality through means other than sight. That is where she would usually sit.
You think she did it to herself? Maybe she was trying to wriggle out of a deal with a devious demon.
She wasn't like that! And she wouldn't do that for the more common reasons either.
No, of course not. That's not really what happened...
... She wasn't a morning person.
Oh dear, she probably walked out of her room still half asleep.
Just like what happened with little Flurny.
Oh yeah, that little bugger was always trying to sneak into the kitchen when I wasn't looking.
There wasn't nearly as much of a mess back then. Though I suppose he did fall from a lower floor.
Betrayed by a misaligned agent of time.
To think something as simple as this could lead to such a tragedy...
Though I admit it is quite a relief to hear that no witch here would do something so awful to an innocent girl.
You can say that again! I didn't think I'd ever feel the need to sleep with a knife under my pillow before all this!
This is unbefitting of a practionner of the arcane arts. You're a witch, not a vulgar commoner.
You did a great job dearie. I'm so glad you figured it out. Safe travels now.
You turn around and walk to the invocation circle with the satisfaction of a job well done.
Apart from that strange feeling that the puzzle is incomplete.
It's probably nothing.
That's not how I remember things going down.
